defs.docs: Terminal formatting library.

attributes.value: ! This crate provides the `Terminal` trait, which abstracts over an [ANSI
! Terminal][ansi] to provide color printing, among other things. There are two
! implementations, the `TerminfoTerminal`, which uses control characters from
! a [terminfo][ti] database, and `WinConsole`, which uses the [Win32 Console

defs.docs: Terminal attributes for use with term.attr().

attributes.value: / Terminal attributes for use with term.attr().
/ Most attributes can only be turned on and must be turned off with term.reset().
/ The ones that can be turned off explicitly take a boolean value.
/ Color is also represented as an attribute for convenience.

defs.name: Terminal
defs.docs:
A terminal with similar capabilities to an ANSI Terminal
 (foreground/background colors etc).

attributes.value: / A terminal with similar capabilities to an ANSI Terminal

defs.name: Output
defs.docs: The terminal's output writer type.

defs.name: fg
defs.docs: Sets the foreground color to the given color.

attributes.value: / Sets the foreground color to the given color.
/ If the color is a bright color, but the terminal only supports 8 colors,
/ the corresponding normal color will be used instead.
/ Returns `Ok(true)` if the color was set, `Ok(false)` otherwise, and `Err(e)`
/ if there was an I/O error.

defs.name: bg
defs.docs: Sets the background color to the given color.

attributes.value: / Sets the background color to the given color.
/ If the color is a bright color, but the terminal only supports 8 colors,
/ the corresponding normal color will be used instead.
/ Returns `Ok(true)` if the color was set, `Ok(false)` otherwise, and `Err(e)`
/ if there was an I/O error.

defs.name: attr
defs.docs:
Sets the given terminal attribute, if supported. Returns `Ok(true)`
 if the attribute was supported, `Ok(false)` otherwise, and `Err(e)` if
 there was an I/O error.

defs.name: reset
defs.docs: Resets all terminal attributes and colors to their defaults.

attributes.value: / Resets all terminal attributes and colors to their defaults.
/ Returns `Ok(true)` if the terminal was reset, `Ok(false)` otherwise, and `Err(e)` if there
/ That means the reset command may get buffered so, if you aren't planning on doing anything
/ else that might flush stdout's buffer (e.g., writing a line of text), you should flush after
